text:
Article 50 and Brexit: A simple guide to how Britain will leave the EU By danjmartin | Posted: March 28, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (0) 
Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to commence Brexit on Wednesday by invoking Article 50. 
It comes some eight months after a majority of 52 per cent of British voters said they wanted to leave the EU . 
Mrs May is to notify other European leaders of Britain's intention to quit EU and in doing so launch two years of intense negotiations to set out the terms on which the departure takes place. 
But how does it all work? And what does it all mean? 
What is Article 50? 
It is a clause in the Treaty of Lisbon by which EU member states can invoke to formally commence the process of exiting the union. 
It outlines the process for a member state quitting the union. 
When will it be triggered? 
Prime Minister Theresa May has said she intends to activate Article 50 on Wednesday. 
So then Britain's out of the EU? 
No, not even nearly. 
It will mark the beginning of what is set to be a lengthy and complex set of negotiations between Britain and remaining EU members about the terms of Brexit. 
When will we actually leave then? 
To be honest, nobody really knows. 
The process is meant to take two years, so in theory Britain will be a former EU member by April 2019. 
One high ranking EU official has said he thinks it might take a decade for Britain to extricate itself from the EU . 
What happens after Article 50 is triggered? 
In a month, 27 leaders from the EU will hold a summit to discuss what they want out of Brexit negotiations. 
Theresa May will not be one of those round the table. 
In May, the European Commission (corr) will publish negotiating guidelines based on the mandate the EU leaders give it. 
After that the negotiations will begin in earnest – on subjects such as trade, immigration, future foreign policy, laws, the rights of Britonsin Europe and EU nationals living in the UK and many others. 
What do we do during the negotiations? 
Keep calm and carry on. 
We're still in the EU until we are legally out. 
Britain will still be in the single market and subject to all the EU laws and rules, including the freedom of movement. 
The UK has, however, forfeited its rotating presidency of the European Council – which was scheduled for the second half of 2017 – to concentrate on Brexit negotiations. 
Legally, nothing prevents the UK from taking part in adopting EU acts that are unrelated to Brexit during the negotiation period. 
However, the UK cannot participate in the decisions taken by the council concerning Brexit negotiations. 
How did it come to this? 
In Leicester, people voted to remain in the EU but narrowly by 51.1 per cent to 48.9 per cent on a 65.1 per cent turn out. 
But parts of the county voted overwhelmingly to leave the EU. 
In Oadby and Wigston 55 per cent of voters opted to leave with 61 per cent in North West Leicestershire. 
In Charnwood the Leave campaign secure 54 per cent of the vote and in Melton it was 58 per cent. 
Some 60 per cent of Blaby voters opted for Leave with 51 per cent in Harborough and Rutland. 
Hinckley and Bosworth came out for leave by 60.3 per cent.
